instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.PP1V05_SO: What is PP1V05_SO? This is a typo of PP1V05_S0 When you see PP1V05_SO, assume they meant to type PP1V05_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!

Hey guys! 

Hoping I can get some help with this one. 

I received a Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820-000165 in from a customer for repair with the reported fault as an intermittent boot issue. 

The customer said the Macbook wont boot, which has been happening intermittently, but getting worse and worse over time, and now wont boot at all

I got one boot out of it as soon as I received it then nothing.

Opened her up to find liquid damage on <CHIP>U3510</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C3510</CAPACITOR> & on <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> <CHIP>TPS51916</CHIP> resistors <RESISTOR>R7612</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7615</CAPACITOR>. 

Cleaned up those areas & replaced <RESISTOR>R7612</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7615</CAPACITOR> - got a boot, right after, did a restart and then no boot, back to 20 - 30 seconds on fan spin then nothing. 

Here is where I'm stuck - during boot I have all rails present, for about 20 - 30 seconds then nothing no boot. 

These are the following measurements that I hope can help point towards a resolution or help me understand what's happening! 

<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_VFB2_R</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_VFB2</SIGNAL> = 1v
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_COMP2_R</SIGNAL> = 1.9v 
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_LL</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_VBST_R</SIGNAL> = 8.45v
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> = 2v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4v during boot, drops to 1 volt after 
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4S3_FUNC</SIGNAL> = missing 
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4RS3_COMP1</SIGNAL> = 2v
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4S3_VFB1</SIGNAL> = missing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = missing
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL> = missing
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_RF</SIGNAL> = 1.25v
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4S3_DRVH</SIGNAL> = missing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.04v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.3 during boot, then jumps to 340.00v 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 2.7v during boot then missing after 

I also have a short on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SO</SIGNAL> which I find odd, because it measures fine during boot - I really hope this helps shed light on how I'm not able to solve this one! 

Thanks for any of your time and help in advance! 

Max

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4v during boot, drops to 1 volt after"
Do you mean, it drops after 20-30s?
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> MUST stay always high, once charger is coneccted; even in S5 state, when board is off.
I'm wonder why didn't mention drop voltage on 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> at same time; both controlled by above mentioned signal.

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.3 during boot, then jumps to 340.00v"
You may want to say "mV", isn't?

You've posted many unneded signals; try to post something more usefull please.
Like <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSWPWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and all RTC signals.
Specify if any is not stable and time for drop, if is the case.
Also check <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, if stable.

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
Thanks so much! I'm excited to be a part of it, and hopefully become a better repairer as well :) 

Thanks for your prompt reply as well. 

To be clear, I've just timed it, I get fan spin for 10 seconds, and during this time is what I'm talking about when I say during boot, and then after. 

In saying that I've just checked again, and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.4v during fan spin (10 seconds) then stay on after - I must have measured incorrectly 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 2.7v during boot then missing after the fan spin (10 seconds) 

You're correct about my measurement on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - didn't realise my multi meter was changing mode on it's own :/ how embarrassing LOL  

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is 3.3v during fan spin, then 340.00mV after.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v 
<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v (odd when I measured this just now it caused fan spin for the 10 seconds again) 
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.6v

With the RTC (real time clock) do you mean <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> SLG3NB148CV. 

Thanks again for your time, I clearly have a lot to learn. 

Max

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1v"
All the time, or just when fan goes off?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> too.
If is OK, then reball SMC.

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
Doubled checked everything. 

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> = 3.2V 

Would you still recommend reball SMC? 

May I ask either way how you came to that so I know for next time?? :) 

Max

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
You've posted lower value for <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> before.
That was the reason of my previous post; check the note from page 59.

Check if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is stable high.
Also test if board stays on removing <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>.
Inspect <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion.

threads.title: Macbook Air 820-000165 - liquid damage repair - getting trolled & getting no where!
threads.message:
I see. 

I've checked <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and it's 3.3v - stable however if I moved my positive probe on the pad, the board would fan spin for 10 seconds again.  
I removed <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> and board still fan spins for 10 seconds then nothing
After removing <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> moving positive probes on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> does not cause fan to spin for 10 seconds again
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> has no corrosion 

I hope this helps :/ 

Max
